original: Majjhima Nikāya 2
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Sabbāsavasutta
analyzed: sabbāsavasutta
translated: All Cankers

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Savatthi in Jeta’s Grove, Anathapindika’s Park.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Bhikkhus!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “sabbāsavasaṁvarapariyāyaṁ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi.
analyzed: sabba āsava savara pariyāyam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you a section on the restraint of all the cankers.

original: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato
translated: “Yes, venerable sir,” the bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Jānato ahaṁ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
analyzed: jānataḥ aha bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi no a jānataḥ no a passataḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, I say that the destruction of the cankers occurs in dependence on wisdom.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato kiñca passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi?
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave jānataḥ kiñca passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi
translated: And what is the wisdom in dependence on which the destruction of the cankers occurs?

original: Yoniso ca manasikāraṁ ayoniso ca manasikāraṁ.
analyzed: yonisaḥ ca manasikāram a yonisaḥ ca manasikāra
translated: Wise attention and unwise attention.

original: Ayoniso, bhikkhave, manasikaroto anuppannā ceva āsavā uppajjanti, uppannā ca āsavā pavaḍḍhanti;
analyzed: ayonisaḥ bhikkhave manasikarotaḥ anuppannā ca iva āsavāḥ uppajjanti uppannā ca āsavā pavaḍḍhanti
translated: When you don’t attend inappropriately, unarisen effluents don’t arise, and arisen effluents are abandoned.

original: yoniso ca kho, bhikkhave, manasikaroto anuppannā ceva āsavā na uppajjanti, uppannā ca āsavā pahīyanti.🔽Atthi, bhikkhave, āsavā dassanā pahātabbā, atthi āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā, atthi āsavā🔽paṭisevanā pahātabbā, atthi āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā, atthi āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā,
analyzed: yonisaḥ ca kho bhikkhave manasikarotaḥ anuppannā ca iva āsavā na uppajjanti uppannā ca āsavā pahīyanti  atthi bhikkhave āsavā dassanā pahātabbā atthi āsavā savarā pahātabbā atthi āsavā  paṭisevanā pahātabbā atthi āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā atthi āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā
translated: When you attend appropriately, unarisen effluents don’t arise, and arisen effluents are abandoned.

original: atthi āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā, atthi āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā.🔽1. Dassanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: atthi āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā atthi āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā  dassana apahātabba āsava
translated: “There are effluents to be abandoned by seeing, effluents to be abandoned by restraining, effluents to be abandoned by avoiding, effluents to be abandoned by tolerating, effluents to be abandoned by removing, effluents to be abandoned by developing, and effluents to be abandoned by using.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā dassanā pahātabbā?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ dassanā pahātabbā
translated: “And what are the effluents to be abandoned by seeing?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto—
analyzed: idha bhikkhave assutavā puthujjanaḥ ariyānam a dassāvī ariya dhammassa a kovidaḥ ariya dhamme a vinītaḥ sappurisānam a dassāvī sappurisa dhammassa a kovidaḥ sappurisa dhamme a vinītaḥ
translated: There is the case where an uninstructed run-of-the-mill person who has not seen the noble ones, is not versed in the teachings of the noble ones, is not trained in the teachings of the noble ones,

original: manasikaraṇīye dhamme nappajānāti, amanasikaraṇīye dhamme nappajānāti.
analyzed: manasikaraṇīye dhamme na ppajānāti a manasikaraṇīye dhamme na ppajānāti
translated: He doesn’t understand what things should be attended to and what things should not be attended to.

original: So manasikaraṇīye dhamme appajānanto amanasikaraṇīye dhamme appajānanto, ye dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā, te dhamme manasi karoti, ye dhammā manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme na manasi karoti.
analyzed: so manasikaraṇīye dhamme appajānantaḥ a manasikaraṇīye dhamme appajānantaḥ ye dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme manasi karoti ye dhammā manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme na manasi karoti
translated: Not understanding these things, he attends to things that should not be attended to and does not attend to things that should be attended to.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme manasi karoti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave dhammāḥ na manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme manasi karoti
translated: And what are the things that should not be attended to that he attends to?

original: Yassa, bhikkhave, dhamme manasikaroto anuppanno vā kāmāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā kāmāsavo pavaḍḍhati;
analyzed: yassa bhikkhave dhamme manasikarotaḥ anuppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: When he attends to things in a way that causes the unarisen inflow of sensuality to arise, or the arisen inflow of sensuality to increase,

original: anuppanno vā bhavāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā bhavāsavo pavaḍḍhati;
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: the unarisen inflow of becoming to arise, or the arisen inflow of becoming to increase,

original: anuppanno vā avijjāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā avijjāsavo pavaḍḍhati—
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: the unarisen inflow of ignorance to arise, or the arisen inflow of ignorance to increase,

original: ime dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme manasi karoti.
analyzed: ime dhammā na manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme manasi karoti
translated: he attends to things that should not be attended to.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme na manasi karoti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave dhammāḥ manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme na manasi karoti
translated: And what are the things that should be attended to that he does not attend to?

original: Yassa, bhikkhave, dhamme manasikaroto anuppanno vā kāmāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā kāmāsavo pahīyati;
analyzed: yassa bhikkhave dhamme manasikarotaḥ anuppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ pahīyati
translated: When you attend unwisely to a state, the fetter of sensuality that has not arisen comes into being, and the fetter of sensuality that has arisen increases.

original: anuppanno vā bhavāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā bhavāsavo pahīyati;
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ pahīyati
translated: The fetter of being that has not arisen comes into being, and the fetter of being that has arisen increases.

original: anuppanno vā avijjāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā avijjāsavo pahīyati—🔽ime dhammā manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme na manasi karoti.
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ pahīyati  ime dhammā manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme na manasi karoti
translated: The fetter of ignorance that has not arisen comes into being, and the fetter of ignorance that has arisen increases.🔽These are states that you should attend to. But you attend unwisely to states that you should not attend to, and you do not attend wisely to states that you should attend to.

original: Tassa amanasikaraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ manasikārā manasikaraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ amanasikārā anuppannā ceva āsavā uppajjanti uppannā ca āsavā pavaḍḍhanti.
analyzed: tassa a manasikaraṇīyānam dhammānam manasikārāḥ manasikaraṇīyānam dhammānam a manasikārāḥ anuppannā ca iva āsavā uppajjanti uppannā ca āsavā pavaḍḍhanti
translated: As you do so, unarisen effluents come into being, and arisen effluents increase.

original: So evaṁ ayoniso manasi karoti:
analyzed: saḥ evam ayonisaḥ manasi karoti
translated: You attend unwisely to this:

original: ‘ahosiṁ nu kho ahaṁ atītamaddhānaṁ? Na nu kho ahosiṁ atītamaddhānaṁ? Kiṁ nu kho ahosiṁ🔽atītamaddhānaṁ? Kathaṁ nu kho ahosiṁ atītamaddhānaṁ? Kiṁ hutvā kiṁ ahosiṁ nu kho🔽ahaṁ atītamaddhānaṁ?
analyzed: ahosim nu kho aham atīta maddhāna na nu kho ahosim atīta maddhāna kim nu kho ahosi 🔽atīta maddhāna katham nu kho ahosim atīta maddhāna kim hutvā kim ahosim nu kho 🔽aham
translated: ‘Was I in the past? Was I not in the past? What was I in the past? Having been what, what was I in the past?

original: Bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ? Na nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ? Kiṁ
analyzed: bhavissāmi nu kho aham anāgata maddhāna na nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna ki
translated: Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future?

original: nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ? Kathaṁ nu kho bhavissāmi anāgatamaddhānaṁ? Kiṁ🔽hutvā kiṁ bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṁ anāgatamaddhānan’ti?
analyzed: nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna katham nu kho bhavissāmi anāgata maddhāna ki  hutvā kim bhavissāmi nu khalu aham anāgatam addhānam ti
translated: What shall I be in the future? How shall I be in the future? Having been what, what shall I be in the future?

original: Etarahi vā paccuppannamaddhānaṁ ajjhattaṁ kathaṅkathī hoti:
analyzed: etarahi vā paccuppannam addhānam ajjhattam kathaṅkathī hoti
translated: Or else he is perplexed about the present thus:

original: ‘ahaṁ nu khosmi? No nu khosmi? Kiṁ nu khosmi? Kathaṁ nu khosmi? Ayaṁ nu kho satto kuto āgato? So kuhiṁ gāmī bhavissatī’ti?
analyzed: aham nu kho asmi no nu kho asmi kim nu kho asmi katham nu kho asmi ayam nu kho satto kutas āgataḥ saḥ kuhim gāmī bhavissati iti
translated: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This being, this living thing, this person: where has it come from? Where is it bound? ‘

original: Tassa evaṁ ayoniso manasikaroto channaṁ diṭṭhīnaṁ aññatarā diṭṭhi uppajjati.🔽‘Atthi me attā’ti vā assa saccato thetato diṭṭhi uppajjati;🔽‘natthi me attā’ti vā assa saccato thetato diṭṭhi uppajjati;
analyzed: tassa evam ayonisas manasikarotaḥ channam diṭṭhīnam aññatarā diṭṭhi uppajjati  atthi me attā iti vai assa saccatas thetatas diṭṭhi uppajjati  natthi me attā ati vai assa saccatas thetatas diṭṭhi uppajjati
translated: As he is thus perplexed, one of six kinds of view arises in him:🔽The view arises in him thus: ‘My self is material, formless, percipient,633🔽The view arises in him thus: ‘My self is formless, non-percipient,

original: ‘attanāva attānaṁ sañjānāmī’ti vā assa saccato thetato diṭṭhi uppajjati;
analyzed: attanā ava attānam sañjānāmi iti vai assa saccataḥ thetataḥ diṭṭhi uppajjati
translated: The view arises in him thus: ‘My self is percipient and non-percipient,

original: ‘attanāva anattānaṁ sañjānāmī’ti vā assa saccato thetato diṭṭhi uppajjati;
analyzed: attanā va anattānam sañjānāmi iti vai assa saccataḥ thetataḥ diṭṭhi uppajjati
translated: The view occurs to him: ‘It is by me that I am known.’

original: ‘anattanāva attānaṁ sañjānāmī’ti vā assa saccato thetato diṭṭhi uppajjati;
analyzed: an attanā ava attānam sañjānāmi iti vai assa saccataḥ thetataḥ diṭṭhi uppajjati
translated: The view occurs to him: ‘It is by something other than me that I am known.’

original: atha vā panassa evaṁ diṭṭhi hoti:
analyzed: atha vā panassa evam diṭṭhi hoti
translated: Or else the view occurs to him:

original: ‘yo me ayaṁ attā vado vedeyyo tatra tatra kalyāṇapāpakānaṁ kammānaṁ vipākaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti
analyzed: yaḥ me ayam attā vadaḥ vedeyyaḥ tatra tatra kalyāṇa pāpakānam kammānam vipākam paṭisaveda iti
translated: ‘This self of mine that speaks and feels and experiences here and there the result of good and bad actions—

original: so kho pana me ayaṁ attā nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṁ tatheva ṭhassatī’ti.
analyzed: saḥ kho pana me ayam attā niccaḥ dhuvaḥ sassataḥ a vipariṇāma dhammo sassati samam tathā iva ṭhassati iti
translated: this self of mine is permanent, everlasting, eternal, not subject to change, and will endure as long as eternity.’

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, diṭṭhigataṁ diṭṭhigahanaṁ diṭṭhikantāraṁ diṭṭhivisūkaṁ diṭṭhivipphanditaṁ diṭṭhisaṁyojanaṁ.🔽Diṭṭhisaṁyojanasaṁyutto, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi;
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave diṭṭhi gatam diṭṭhi gahanam diṭṭhi kantāram diṭṭhi visūkam diṭṭhi vipphanditam diṭṭhi sayojana  diṭṭhi sayojana sayuttaḥ bhikkhave assutavā puthujjanaḥ na parimuccati jātiyāḥ jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi
translated: This, bhikkhus, is called a view, a viewpoint, a view-position, a view-obsession, a view-conviction, a view-preference, a view-bias, a view-dependence, a view-acquisition, a view-quarrel, a view-provocation, a view-plunging, a view-stinging, a view-torment, a view-affliction, a view-foetus, a view-root, a view-wound, a view-thread, a view-plague, a view-thorn.🔽“Bhikkhus, the uninstructed worldling, bhikkhus, is affected by feelings born of contact with ignorance. He does not know and see as it really is the origination and passing away of these feelings, their satisfaction, unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them.🔽He is not freed from birth, aging, and death; from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair; he is not freed from suffering, I say.

original: ‘na parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
analyzed: na parimuccati dukkhasma ati vadāmi
translated: “But, bhikkhus, the instructed noble disciple, bhikkhus, is affected by feelings born of contact with ignorance. He knows and sees as it really is the origination and passing away of these feelings, their satisfaction, unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them.

original: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako—
analyzed: sutavā ca kho bhikkhave ariya sāvako
translated: A well-taught noble disciple🔽who has seen the noble ones, is well-versed in the noble ones’ teachings, trains in accordance with the noble ones’ teachings,

original: ariyānaṁ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṁ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto—
analyzed: ariyānam dassāvī ariya dhammassa kovidaḥ ariya dhamme su vinītaḥ sappurisānam dassāvī sappurisa dhammassa kovidaḥ sappurisa dhamme su vinītaḥ
translated: and who has seen good persons, is well-versed in the good persons’ teachings, and trains in accordance with the good persons’ teachings,

original: manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānāti amanasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānāti.
analyzed: manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānāti a manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānāti
translated: knows what things should be attended to and what things should not be attended to.🔽Knowing what things should be attended to and what things should not be attended to,

original: So manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānanto amanasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānanto ye dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme na manasi karoti, ye dhammā manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme manasi karoti.
analyzed: saḥ manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānantaḥ a manasikaraṇīye dhamme pajānantaḥ ye dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme na manasi karoti ye dhammā manasikaraṇīyā te dhamme manasi karoti
translated: he does not attend to things that should not be attended to and attends to things that should be attended to.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme na manasi karoti?🔽Yassa, bhikkhave, dhamme manasikaroto anuppanno vā kāmāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā kāmāsavo pavaḍḍhati;
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave dhammāḥ na manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme na manasi karoti  yassa bhikkhave dhamme manasikarotaḥ anuppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: “And what things should not be attended to that he does not attend to?🔽When he attends to things that give rise to the unarisen taint of sensual desire, the unarisen taint of sensual desire arises, and when arisen, the taint of sensual desire increases.

original: anuppanno vā bhavāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā bhavāsavo pavaḍḍhati;
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: When he attends to things that give rise to the unarisen taint of existence, the unarisen taint of existence arises, and when arisen, the taint of existence increases.

original: anuppanno vā avijjāsavo uppajjati, uppanno vā avijjāsavo pavaḍḍhati—
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ uppajjati uppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: The stress that has not yet arisen comes into being, and the stress that has arisen increases.

original: ime dhammā na manasikaraṇīyā, ye dhamme na manasi karoti.
analyzed: ime dhammāḥ na manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme na manasi karoti
translated: These are things you should not pay attention to, and he pays attention to them.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme manasi karoti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave dhammāḥ manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme manasi karoti
translated: “And what are the things you should pay attention to, and he pays attention to them?

original: Yassa, bhikkhave, dhamme manasikaroto anuppanno vā kāmāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā kāmāsavo pahīyati;
analyzed: yassa bhikkhave dhamme manasikarotaḥ anuppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā kāma āsavaḥ pahīyati
translated: When he pays attention to things, the stress that has not yet arisen doesn’t come into being, and the stress that has arisen is abandoned.

original: anuppanno vā bhavāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā bhavāsavo pahīyati;
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā bhava āsavaḥ pahīyati
translated: The stress that has not yet arisen doesn’t come into being, and the stress that has arisen is abandoned.

original: anuppanno vā avijjāsavo na uppajjati, uppanno vā avijjāsavo pahīyati—
analyzed: anuppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ na uppajjati uppannaḥ vā avijjā āsavaḥ pahīyati
translated: The stress that has not yet arisen doesn’t come into being, and the stress that has arisen is abandoned.

original: ime dhammā manasikaraṇīyā ye dhamme manasi karoti.
analyzed: ime dhammāḥ manasikaraṇīyāḥ ye dhamme manasi karoti
translated: These are things you should pay attention to, and he pays attention to them.

original: Tassa amanasikaraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ amanasikārā manasikaraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ manasikārā anuppannā ceva āsavā na uppajjanti, uppannā ca āsavā pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa a manasikaraṇīyānam dhammānam a manasikārāḥ manasikaraṇīyānam dhammānam manasikārāḥ anuppannā ca iva āsavā na uppajjanti uppannā ca āsavā pahīyanti
translated: When he doesn’t pay attention to things you shouldn’t pay attention to, and pays attention to things you should pay attention to, then unarisen corruptions do not come into being, and arisen corruptions are abandoned.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yoniso manasi karoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yoniso manasi karoti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhanti yonisas manasi karoti ayam dukkha samudayo ti yonisas manasi karoti
translated: He gives close attention to ‘This is suffering’ … He gives close attention to ‘This is the origin of suffering’ …

original: ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yoniso manasi karoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yoniso manasi karoti.
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yonisas manasi karoti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yonisaḥ manasi karoti
translated: He gives close attention to ‘this is suffering’ … to ‘this is the origin of suffering’ … to ‘this is the cessation of suffering’ … to ‘this is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: Tassa evaṁ yoniso manasikaroto tīṇi saṁyojanāni pahīyanti—
analyzed: tassa evam yonisas manasikarotaḥ tīṇi sayojanāni pahīyanti
translated: As he gives close attention to them, three fetters are abandoned in him:

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhi, vicikicchā, sīlabbataparāmāso.
analyzed: sa kāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ
translated: personality view, doubt, and grasping at precepts and observances.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā dassanā pahātabbā.🔽2. Saṁvarāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavāḥ dassanā pahātabbā  savara apahātabba āsava
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by seeing.🔽The taints to be abandoned by restraining

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā savarā pahātabbā
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by restraining?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cakkhundriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cakkhu indriya savara savutaḥ viharati
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells restrained with the restraint of the eye faculty.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, cakkhundriyasaṁvaraṁ asaṁvutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, cakkhundriyasaṁvaraṁ saṁvutassa viharato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave cakkhu indriya savaram a savutassa viharataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhā cakkhu indriya savaram savutassa viharataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: The taints that would assail him if he were to dwell unrestrained with the restraint of the eye faculty do not assail him when he dwells restrained with the restraint of the eye faculty.

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso sotindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati …pe…🔽ghānindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati …pe…🔽jivhindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati …pe…
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ viharati pe  viharati pe  viharati pe
translated: He lives with the faculty of nose …🔽He lives with the faculty of tongue …

original: kāyindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati …pe…
analyzed: viharati pe
translated: He lives with the faculty of body …

original: manindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati.🔽Yañhissa, bhikkhave, manindriyasaṁvaraṁ asaṁvutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, manindriyasaṁvaraṁ saṁvutassa viharato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: viharati  yañhi ssa bhikkhave manindriya savaram a savutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ manindriya savaram savutassa viharato eva te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: He lives with the faculty of mind restrained,🔽and thereby the taints, vexation, or fever that would arise if he were not to restrain the faculty of mind do not arise for him.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, saṁvaraṁ asaṁvutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, saṁvaraṁ saṁvutassa viharato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.🔽Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave savaram asavutassa viharataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhā savaram savutassa viharataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti  ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā savarā pahātabbā
translated: And thereby the taints, vexation, or fever that would arise if he were not to restrain the faculties do not arise for him.

original: 3. Paṭisevanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: paṭisevana apahātabba āsava
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by restraining.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by using?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cīvaram paṭisevati
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu makes use of a robe, having reflected on it wisely:

original: ‘yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva hirikopīnappaṭicchādanatthaṁ’.
analyzed: yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya uṇhassa paṭighātāya ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassānam paṭighātāya yāvat eva
translated: ‘I do so only to ward off the cold, to ward off the heat, to ward off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; only to conceal the private parts.’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso piṇḍapātaṁ paṭisevati:🔽‘neva davāya, na madāya, na maṇḍanāya, na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā🔽yāpanāya, vihiṁsūparatiyā, brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ piṇḍapātam paṭisevati  na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā  yāpanāya brahmacariya anuggahāya iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi
translated: “He makes use of almsfood, having reflected on it wisely:

original: navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro ca’.
analyzed: navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca
translated: ‘Not for fun, for indulgence, for adornment, or for beautification, but only to maintain this body, to keep it safe from harm, and to support spiritual practice, thinking, “Thus I shall terminate old feelings without arousing new feelings and I shall be healthy, blameless, and happy.”’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso senāsanaṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ senāsanam paṭisevati
translated: “He makes use of a resting place, having reflected on it wisely:

original: ‘yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva utuparissayavinodanapaṭisallānārāmatthaṁ’.
analyzed: yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya uṇhassa paṭighātāya ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassānam paṭighātāya yāvat eva utu parissaya vinodana paṭisallāna ārāmattha
translated: ‘just to ward off the danger of cold, to ward off the danger of heat, to ward off the danger of biting insects, mosquitoes, wind, the sun, and serpents; just for the sake of feeling pleasure, for the sake of feeling refreshed; for the sake of gladdening, of arousing, of pleasing the mind and body; and for the sake of helping the spiritual life.’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisas gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram paṭisevati
translated: He uses the requisite of medicine as a cure for sickness after careful consideration:

original: ‘yāvadeva uppannānaṁ veyyābādhikānaṁ vedanānaṁ paṭighātāya, abyābajjhaparamatāya’.
analyzed: yāvat eva uppannānam veyyābādhikānam vedanānam paṭighātāya a byābajjha parama tāya
translated: ‘just to ward off the pains of presently arisen illness and for the sake of living without affliction.’

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, appaṭisevato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, paṭisevato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave appaṭisevataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhā paṭisevataḥ eva te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: The taints, vexation, and fever that would arise if he did not use the requisite of medicine as a cure for sickness after careful consideration do not arise for him when he uses it after careful consideration.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by use.

original: 4. Adhivāsanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: adhivāsana apahātabba āsava
translated: The taints to be abandoned by enduring

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbā
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by enduring?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa, jighacchāya
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ khamaḥ hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu endures cold and heat…

original: pipāsāya. Ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ, duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ,
analyzed: pipāsāya duruttānam durāgatānam vacana pathāna
translated: for thirst. He endures contact with flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and serpents; rough words, and unwelcome contacts.

original: uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ
analyzed: uppannānam sārīrikānam vedanānam dukkhānam tibbānam kharānam kaṭukānam asātānam amanāpānam
translated: He endures arisen bodily feelings that are painful, racking, sharp, piercing, disagreeable, distressing, and life-threatening.

original: pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
analyzed: adhivāsaka jātikaḥ hoti
translated: He is one who endures.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, anadhivāsayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, adhivāsayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave an adhivāsayataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ adhivāsayataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: The taints, vexation, and fever that would arise if he did not endure would not arise for him if he endures.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā.🔽5. Parivajjanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbā  parivajjana apahātabba āsava
translated: These are called taints to be abandoned by enduring.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso caṇḍaṁ hatthiṁ parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ assaṁ
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ caṇḍam hatthim parivajjeti caṇḍam assa
translated: “And what taints are to be abandoned by avoiding?

original: parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ goṇaṁ parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ kukkuraṁ parivajjeti, ahiṁ khāṇuṁ kaṇṭakaṭṭhānaṁ
analyzed: parivajja iti caṇḍam goṇam parivajja iti caṇḍam kukkuram parivajja iti ahim khāṇum kaṇṭakaṭṭhāna
translated: There is the case where a monk, reflecting appropriately, avoids a wild elephant, a wild horse, a wild bull, a wild dog, a snake, a stump, a bramble patch, a chasm, a cliff, a cesspool, an open sewer.

original: sobbhaṁ papātaṁ candanikaṁ oḷigallaṁ.
analyzed: papātam candanikam oḷigalla
translated: He avoids sitting in the sorts of seat where people might criticize him.

original: Yathārūpe anāsane nisinnaṁ yathārūpe agocare carantaṁ yathārūpe pāpake mitte bhajantaṁ
analyzed: yathārūpe anāsane nisinnam yathārūpe agocare carantam yathārūpe pāpake mitte bhajanta
translated: “As to the kind of seat he sits on, the kind of resort he resorts to, the kind of friends he cultivates,

original: viññū sabrahmacārī pāpakesu ṭhānesu okappeyyuṁ, so tañca anāsanaṁ tañca agocaraṁ
analyzed: viññū sabrahmacārī pāpakesu ṭhānesu okappeyyu saḥ tat ca anāsanam tat ca agocara
translated: “Whatever seat a wise person who lives the holy life would not sit on, whatever resort a wise person who lives the holy life would not resort to, whatever bad friends a wise person who lives the holy life would not associate with,🔽he, having reflected on it with wise reflection, avoids that seat, that resort,

original: te ca pāpake mitte paṭisaṅkhā yoniso parivajjeti.
analyzed: te ca pāpake mitte paṭisaṅkhā yonisas parivajja iti
translated: and those bad friends.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, aparivajjayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, parivajjayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave a parivajjayataḥ uppajjeyyum āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhā parivajjayataḥ eva te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: The effluents, vexation, or fever that would arise if he did not avoid them do not arise for him when he avoids them.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā.🔽6. Vinodanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā  vinodana apahātabba āsava
translated: These are called effluents to be abandoned by avoiding.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ vinodanā pahātabbā
translated: “And what are effluents to be abandoned by destroying?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ nādhivāseti pajahati
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti pajahati
translated: There is the case where a monk, reflecting appropriately, does not tolerate an arisen thought of sensuality.

original: vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti, uppannaṁ byāpādavitakkaṁ …pe… uppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ
analyzed: vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gama iti uppannam byāpāda vitakkam pe uppannam vihisā vitakka
translated: He abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, & wipes it out of existence. He does not tolerate an arisen thought of ill-will… an arisen thought of harmfulness…

original: …pe… uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: pe uppanna uppanne pāpake akusale dhamme na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: … he doesn’t consent to any evil unwholesome thoughts that have arisen. He abandons them, removes them, does away with them, and annihilates them.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, avinodayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, vinodayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave a vinodayataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ vinodayataḥ eva te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: The effluents, vexation, or fever that would arise if he did not abandon these things do not arise for him when he abandons them.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā.🔽7. Bhāvanāpahātabbaāsava
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavāḥ vinodanā pahātabbā  bhāvanā apahātabba āsava
translated: These are called effluents to be abandoned by using.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso satisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ;
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ bhāvanā pahātabbā  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas sati sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: “And which are the effluents to be abandoned by development?🔽There is the case where a monk, reflecting appropriately, develops the mindfulness factor for awakening dependent on seclusion, dependent on dispassion, dependent on cessation, resulting in letting go.

original: paṭisaṅkhā yoniso dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …pe…🔽vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisas dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti pe  vīriya sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti
translated: Reflecting appropriately, he develops the investigation-of-phenomena factor for awakening…🔽the persistence factor for awakening…

original: pītisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …🔽passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …
analyzed: pīti sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti  passaddhi sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti
translated: the rapture factor for awakening…🔽the serenity factor for awakening…

original: samādhisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …
analyzed: samādhi sambojjhaṅgam bhāva iti
translated: the concentration factor for awakening…

original: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ.
analyzed: upekkhā sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmi
translated: he develops the enlightenment factor of equanimity, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Yañhissa, bhikkhave, abhāvayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, bhāvayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yañhi ssa bhikkhave a bhāvayataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ bhāvayataḥ eva te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: And so, bhikkhus, the taints that would arise in him if he did not develop these things do not arise for him when he develops them.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavāḥ bhāvanā pahātabbā
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by development.

original: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ye āsavā dassanā pahātabbā te dassanā pahīnā honti,
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave bhikkhuno ye āsavāḥ dassanā pahātabbā te dassanā pahīnā honti
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu has seen these taints as they actually are, their origin, their cessation, and the way leading to their cessation, then he has no perplexity or doubt that, having directly known and realized this Dhamma for himself, he might declare:🔽‘The taints that are to be abandoned by seeing have been abandoned by me through direct knowledge.

original: ye āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā te saṁvarā pahīnā honti, ye āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā🔽te paṭisevanā pahīnā honti, ye āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā te adhivāsanā pahīnā honti,
analyzed: ye āsavā savarā pahātabbā te savarā pahīnāḥ honti ye āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā  te paṭisevanā pahīnāḥ honti ye āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbā te adhivāsanā pahīnāḥ honti
translated: The taints that are to be abandoned by restraining have been abandoned by me through restraint. The taints that are to be abandoned by using have been abandoned by me through using.🔽The taints that are to be abandoned by enduring have been abandoned by me through enduring.

original: ye āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā te parivajjanā pahīnā honti, ye āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā🔽te vinodanā pahīnā honti, ye āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā te bhāvanā pahīnā honti;
analyzed: ye āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā te parivajjanā pahīnā honti ye āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā 🔽te vinodanā pahīnāḥ honti ye āsavāḥ bhāvanā pahātabbā te bhāvanā pahīnāḥ honti
translated: The taints that are to be abandoned by avoiding have been abandoned by me through avoiding. The taints that are to be abandoned by dispelling have been abandoned by me through dispelling.🔽The taints that are to be abandoned by developing have been abandoned by me through developing.’

original: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave: ‘bhikkhu sabbāsavasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati, acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’”ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhikkhu sabba asava savara savutaḥ viharati dukkhassa ati
translated: This is called a monk who dwells restrained with restraint over all the sense doors. He has cut off craving, thrown off the fetters, and through the complete penetration of conceit he has made an end of suffering.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: The Fortunate One said this.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.🔽Sabbāsavasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti 🔽sabbāsava suttam niṭṭhitam dutiya
translated: The monks were uplifted and greatly rejoiced in what was said by the Fortunate One.
